summary: The document comprises payroll authorization forms and memoranda from the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), focusing on Jane E. Godfrey's employment details, including her roles, salary changes, and terminations. It also covers the administrative protocols for payroll authorization in the U.S. House of Representatives, highlighting the necessity of disclosing any familial ties to Members of Congress as part of new payroll certification requirements introduced in 1977.
key_findings: Jane E. Godfrey served in multiple capacities within the HSCA, such as Secretary and Office Manager, with her salary being adjusted periodically.
It details the administrative workflow for payroll authorization in the U.S. House of Representatives, including the need for approvals from the Committee on House Administration.
A memorandum from January 3, 1977, introduces new payroll certification mandates for staff employees, specifically requiring the disclosure of any family connections to sitting Members of Congress.
The document provides insight into the bureaucratic and procedural dynamics of managing congressional staff in the late 1970s.
